title: S-Equol in Alzheimer's Disease 2 (SEAD2) Trial
description_brief: By doing this study researchers hope to learn if S-equol, a compound that acts like estrogen in the body, causes an increase in mitochondrial activity. Researchers also hope to determine the safety and tolerability of a therapeutic dose of S-equol and whether or not it influences cognition.
description_detailed: Enrolled participants with a diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) will be randomized to receive either S-equol or placebo first, and then cross over to receive the opposite intervention. The study, therefore, consists of two treatment periods with randomly assigned treatment order. Specifically, subjects are randomized to either: (1) S-equol for one month, then placebo for one month; or (2) placebo for one month, then S-equol for one month.

groups.title: S-equol First, Then Placebo
groups.description: This was a cross-over study. Each participant acted as their own control. The order of the interventions was randomized. Each participant spent one month in each intervention arm. In this group, participants initially received S-equol for one month, and at the conclusion of that arm they were switched to the placebo for one month. There was no washout period. The S-equol was provided as 50 mg capsules, which were taken twice daily.

groups.title: Placebo First, Then S-equol
groups.description: This was a cross-over study. Each participant acted as their own control. The order of the interventions was randomized. Each participant spent one month in each intervention arm. In this group, participants initially received placebo for one month, and at the conclusion of that arm they were switched to S-equol for one month. There was no washout period. The S-equol was provided as 50 mg capsules, which were taken twice daily.

groups.title: S-equol First, Then Placebo
groups.description: This group received S-equol for one month, and then crossed over to receive placebo for one month. There was no washout period.

groups.title: Placebo First, Then S-Equol
groups.description: This group received placebo for one month, then crossed over to receive S-equol for one month. There was no washout period.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Cytochrome Oxidase/Citrate Synthase (COX/CS) Activity
outcomeMeasures.description: Cytochrome oxidase (COX) was measured in platelet mitochondria as a pseudo-first order rate constant (sec-1/mg protein), which was determined as a Vmax, spectrophotometrically, by tracking the change in absorbance as reduced cytochrome c is oxidized to oxidized cytochrome C. Citrate synthase (CS) is a soluble mitochondrial matrix enzyme whose activity was determined spectrophotometrically as a Vmax (micromoles/mg protein). Reporting the COX activity as a ratio to CS activity takes mitochondrial mass into account, and normalizes the COX activity per the amount of mitochondria present in the assay sample, with units 1/(seconds multiplied by micromoles).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Due to the pandemic, 1 participant in the Placebo, Then S-equol group did not complete the analysis. This subject was excluded from this primary analysis, and all secondary analyses except for the safety analysis. As the order of the intervention does not matter, all 39 participants who contributed COX/CS data to the final analysis are included. The mean (SD) value reflects the mean of values obtained when the COX/CS value while on placebo was subtracted from the COX/CS score while on S-equol.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Column 1 is the value after completing S-equol minus the value after completing placebo. For S-equol then placebo, this is the Visit 3 minus the Visit 4 COX/CS value. For placebo then S-equol, this is the Visit 4 minus the Visit 3 COX/CS value.

groups.title: Difference (on S-equol Minus on Placebo)
groups.description: Value after completion of S-equol minus value after completion of placebo. For S-equol then placebo, this is the Visit 3 minus the Visit 4 COX/CS value. For placebo then S-equol, this is the Visit 4 minus the Visit 3 COX/CS value.

groups.title: S-equol
groups.description: This is the average COX/CS measured after S-equol (at month 3 for those on S-equol then Placebo, at month 4 for those on Placebo then S-equol)

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: This is the average COX/CS measured after Placebo (at month 3 for those on Placebo then S-equol, at month 4 for those on S-equol then Placebo)

analyses.groupDescription: As the order of the intervention does not matter, all 39 participants who contributed data to the final analysis are included together.
analyses.nonInferiorityComment: We performed a paired T-test analysis to ascertain whether the COX/CS activity while on S-equol was comparable or different than the COX/CS while on placebo. For each participant, the COX/CS value while on S-equol was subtracted from their COX/CS value while on placebo.

outcomeMeasures.title: Pattern of COX Activity Changes While on the Active Treatment Versus Placebo Arms of This Crossover Study.
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants are defined as responders or non-responders depending on the slope of COX/CS activity change. Those in the "Responder" group have a greater slope of COX/CS activity change going from off- to on-S-equol as compared to going from on- to off-S-equol.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Only the 20 participants who had baseline then S-equol then placebo values contributed to this analysis.

groups.title: S-equol Then Placebo Subjects Only
groups.description: Only subjects that received S-equol then placebo were used for this analysis. Those that received placebo then S-equol were excluded from this analysis.

outcomeMeasures.title: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)
outcomeMeasures.description: Scale range: 0-30. A higher score indicates better global cognitive performance.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The one subject missing the COX/CS difference score was excluded from this analysis. The key measure is the difference score. Participants unable to contribute both S-equol and placebo scores were not included in the difference score analysis, but do contribute to the S-equol or placebo scores as available.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Score after completion of S-equol minus score after completion of placebo. For S-equol then placebo, this is the Visit 3 minus the Visit 4 MoCA score. For placebo then S-equol, this is the Visit 4 minus the Visit 3 MoCA score.

groups.title: Difference (on S-equol Minus on Placebo)
groups.description: This is the average within subject MoCA measure after S-equol minus after Placebo (at month 3 minus at month 4 for those on S-eqol then Placebo, at month 4 minus at month 3 for those on Placebo then S-equol)

groups.title: S-equol
groups.description: This is the average MoCA measured after S-equol (at month 3 for those on S-equol then Placebo, at month 4 for those on Placebo then S-equol)

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: This is the average MoCA measured after Placebo (at month 3 for those on Placebo then S-equol, at month 4 for those on S-equol then Placebo)

outcomeMeasures.description: Scale range: 0-70. A lower score indicates better global cognitive performance.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The one subject missing the COX/CS difference score was excluded from this analysis. The key measure is the difference score. Participants unable to contribute both S-equol and placebo scores were not included in the difference score analysis, but do contribute to the S-equol or placebo scores as available.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
outcomeMeasures.description: List of adverse events as reported over the course of the study (safety labs, physical and neurological exams, vital signs, signs and symptoms).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All 40 enrolled participants contributed to the safety data
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 4 Months: From Visit 1 (Day 0) through Visit 1 (end of month 1, +/- 7 days), Visit 2 (end of month 2, +/- 7 days), Visit 3 (end of month 3, +/- 7days), and Post-Interventions Phone Call (end of month 4, +/- 7 days)

groups.title: Prior to Starting Drug or Placebo
groups.description: This group applies to the Lead-in period, which includes the period 1 month (+/- 7 days) between the screening visit and starting the first intervention.

groups.title: While on S-equol
groups.description: This group includes adverse events while on S-equol, regardless of treatment order. Some received S-equol then placebo, and some received placebo then S-equol. All subjects contributed to each group; 20 who started on S-equol and crossed over to placebo, and 20 who started on placebo and crossed over to S-equol. 40 represents the sum of both these arms, as all received S-equol.

groups.title: While on Placebo
groups.description: This group includes adverse events while on placebo, regardless of treatment order. Some received S-equol then placebo, and some received placebo then S-equol. All subjects contributed to each group; 20 who started on S-equol and crossed over to placebo, and 20 who started on placebo and crossed over to S-equol. 40 represents the sum of both these arms, as all received placebo.

groups.title: After Completing Both Drug and Placebo
groups.description: This applies to the post-interventions observation period, which took place 1 month (+/- 7 days) after completing the second intervention arm.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: 4 months: From Visit 1 (Day 0) through Visit 1 (end of month 1, +/- 7 days), Visit 2 (end of month 2, +/- 7 days), Visit 3 (end of month 3, +/- 7days), and Post-Interventions Phone Call (end of month 4, +/- 7 days)
adverseEventsModule.description: Any untoward or unfavorable medical occurrence in a participant, including any abnormal sign (for example, abnormal physical exam or laboratory finding), symptom, or disease, temporally associated with the participant's participation in the research, whether or not considered related to the participant's participation in the research.

eventGroups.title: Prior to Starting Drug or Placebo
eventGroups.description: This includes all 40 participants, prior to the initiation of any treatment (S-equol or placebo).

eventGroups.title: While on S-equol
eventGroups.description: This includes all 40 participants while receiving S-equol 50mg twice daily for one month.

eventGroups.title: While on Placebo
eventGroups.description: This includes all 40 participants while receiving placebo twice daily for one month.

eventGroups.title: After Completing Both Drug and Placebo
eventGroups.description: This includes all 40 participants following completion of their courses of both S-equol and placebo, regardless of treatment order.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention S‑equol is a small molecule (a soy isoflavone metabolite / enantiomer) that acts as a selective estrogen receptor‑β (ERβ) agonist and is being tested to modulate mitochondrial function — i.e., targeting a disease-related pathway rather than serving solely as a symptomatic cognitive stimulant. citeturn0search3turn0search6

Act (trial details & evidence): The SEAD / SEAD2 trials test oral S‑equol versus placebo in people with Alzheimer’s disease to assess whether S‑equol increases mitochondrial activity (platelet cytochrome oxidase activity), and to determine safety/tolerability and effects on cognition. The protocol records identify the drug as S‑equol (also referenced as AUS‑131) and describe doses and crossover/phase 1–2 designs. citeturn1search2turn1search1

Mechanism: Preclinical and human studies describe S‑equol as a non‑hormonal ERβ ligand produced from daidzein that can potentiate mitochondrial enzymes and bioenergetic function in brain and peripheral cells — a mechanistic rationale for disease‑targeted biological effect in AD. This supports classification as a disease‑targeted small molecule rather than a biologic or pure symptomatic cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search7turn0search5

Reflect: Other plausible categories considered — cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric symptom treatment — are less fitting because the stated primary outcome is change in mitochondrial/biomarker activity (disease biology) and the compound is a synthetic small molecule phytoestrogen, not a biologic (e.g., antibody) or a symptomatic neuropsychiatric drug. Therefore the best fit is 'disease-targeted small molecule'. citeturn1search6turn0search2

Web search sources used (key items): Clinical trial records for SEAD / SEAD2 (trial descriptions and design). citeturn1search2turn1search1; Peer‑reviewed studies/reviews establishing S‑equol as an ERβ‑selective small molecule and reporting mitochondrial effects and safety. citeturn0search3turn0search5turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational compound S‑equol (AUS‑131) is a small‑molecule, S‑enantiomer soy isoflavone that acts as a selective estrogen receptor‑β (ERβ) agonist and has been shown in preclinical work to potentiate mitochondrial enzymes and bioenergetic function — the trial's stated primary biological focus is increasing mitochondrial activity (platelet cytochrome oxidase), i.e., targeting cellular metabolism/bioenergetics rather than a purely symptomatic neurotransmitter effect. citeturn0search0turn1search6

Act: Trial details and evidence extracted: the SEAD/SEAD2 program tests oral S‑equol versus placebo in AD participants to assess mitochondrial activity (platelet cytochrome oxidase), safety/tolerability, and cognitive effects (phase 1/2 crossover designs; NCT03101085; a published pilot biomarker trial and related trial reports describe COX activity endpoints). These trial records and the pilot study document the disease‑targeted mitochondrial outcome measure. citeturn0search2turn1search2

Reflect: CADRO mapping — because the intervention is intended to modulate mitochondrial enzymes, bioenergetics and metabolic pathways in AD, the closest and most specific CADRO category is J) Metabolism and Bioenergetics. Although S‑equol is an ERβ ligand (a hormone receptor interaction), the trial's mechanistic rationale and primary biomarker target are mitochondrial/metabolic, so 'J' is a better fit than L) Growth Factors and Hormones. No evidence indicates multiple distinct CADRO targets that would require 'R) Multi‑target'. citeturn0search0turn1search6

Web search sources (key items used to classify): 1) S‑equol as an ERβ‑selective enantiomer (pharmacology). citeturn0search0 2) Preclinical and translational studies showing S‑equol or phytoSERM treatments potentiate brain mitochondrial enzymes (PDH, αKGDH, COX) and bioenergetics. citeturn1search6 3) Published single‑arm pilot trial in AD measuring platelet cytochrome oxidase activity after S‑equol treatment. citeturn1search2 4) SEAD2 clinicaltrials.gov record (NCT03101085) describing the Phase 1/2 crossover testing S‑equol to assess mitochondrial activity, safety/tolerability, and cognition. citeturn0search2 5) Conference/trial report summarizing initial SEAD results and rationale. citeturn0search1
